metadata.titel_preek: Lent and Holy Week: Ash Wednesday and First Sunday in Lent

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God intervenes in the human condition of universal sin and self-deception to justify the ungodly through the substitutionary death of Christ.

subject.identificatie: God (specifically in the person of Jesus Christ)
tekstueel_bewijs: God has shown us a great thing.
Jesus, the Son of God, has voluntarily taken our place.
He has wrought the salvation of his enemies.

object.identificatie: Salvation/Justification of the unrighteous and the removal of the 'sentence'.
tekstueel_bewijs: the salvation of each and every one of us

zender.identificatie: The Holiness and Reality of God
tekstueel_bewijs: the reality of God, the power of God, the holiness of God, who has the absolute right to make demands

ontvanger.identificatie: The Sinners (The Hearers/The Whole Human Race)
tekstueel_bewijs: the salvation of each and every one of us

helper.identificatie: Jesus Christ (as the one who takes the place of the Subject/Receiver)
tekstueel_bewijs: There is Another who has taken the sentence upon himself
helper.rol_van_geest: External help/Indwelling power (implied in 'renew a right spirit')

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin as a Cosmic/Ontological Power and Human Self-Deception
tekstueel_bewijs: the storm of the wrath of God against sin
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is treated not as a mistake but as a condition that requires a divine death to nullify.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of repentance and unflinching self-knowledge.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer/Psalmist
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The preacher explicitly states that the knowledge of grace (Primary) precedes the confession of sin (Secondary).

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has shown us a great thing.
He has wrought the salvation of his enemies.
God sees you as you really are, and he loves you.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We throw ourselves on his mercy.
We do not need to surround ourselves with defenses.

voorbeelden: action has to be taken against evil deeds
The knowledge of grace has preceded the confession of sin.
God is truly able to do away with sin.
let each one find thee mighty to save.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on God's 'ability' (Pouvoir) to save where man is 'helpless'. It moves from a lack of human power to the sufficiency of divine power.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from S2 (Judgment) and ~S1 (Pretense) toward S1 (Grace) via the 'nullification' of S2 by Christ.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Christ takes S2 (the sentence) upon himself, allowing the sinner to move from ~S1 to S1 without the 'exhausting charade'.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Very high; sin is described as a 'storm of wrath' and an 'axis of evil' through the heart.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is rigorously theocentric. It explicitly rejects moralism by defining sin as a theological rather than ethical concept and by making Christ the sole agent of salvation.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: No human being has ever looked at himself more unflinchingly than the author

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as Subject of Active Verbs
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: He has wrought the salvation of his enemies.
The knowledge of grace has preceded the confession of sin.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: While David/the Psalmist is mentioned, he is an example of 'insight' into a condition only God can fix, not a moral model to emulate for salvation.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading: the Psalmist is the 'Receiver' of a mercy that God 'Subjects'.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the 'exhausting charade' and 'unconquerable confidence'.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Monergistic justification; the hearer is the passive beneficiary of Christ's active work.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the human predicament (Ash Wednesday) to the divine solution (The Cross) is seamless and logically consistent.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'Against thee only' and the reality of hurting others is resolved through the definition of sin's essence.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus, the Son of God, has voluntarily taken our place... bearing in his own body the storm of the wrath of God.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit is the one who 'renews a right spirit'—an endowment of new competence.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is an 'axis' through the heart and a 'storm of wrath'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon maintains a perfect actantial structure where God is the Subject of the primary program (Salvation) and the human is the Subject only of the secondary, responsive program (Repentance).

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain as is; this is appropriate for a Lenten/Ash Wednesday context.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The opponent (Sin/Wrath) is already sufficiently intensified.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a masterclass in theocentric preaching. It avoids the 'moralistic trap' by consistently placing God in the active subject position and treating human repentance as a fruit of grace rather than a condition for it.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: While a rhetorical analysis would focus on the use of Tolkien/Solzhenitsyn as illustrations, Greimassian analysis shows they function as 'Opponents' to the human tendency to self-justify.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the Hebrew of Psalm 51; semiotics explains how the sermon uses that text to re-orient the hearer's identity from 'Judge' to 'Receiver'.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that the 'engine' of this sermon is the 'Subject-Switch'—where the hearer realizes they cannot be the Subject of their own cleansing and must rely on the 'Another' (Christ).

appendices.notities: The sermon follows Fleming Rutledge's grammar of grace almost perfectly.
